video.title: How to ace the whiteboard coding interview
video.description:
Learn how to ace a whiteboard coding interview challenge as part of a tech interview. This video shows how to answer common questions  about JavaScript, HTML, CSS, and jQuery.

Presented by Jennifer Bland (http://www.jenniferbland.com).

⭐ Video Outline ⭐

⌨  JavaScript: 1:38
⌨  HTML & CSS: 19:46
⌨  More JavaScript: 28:18
⌨  jQuery: 43:53

topLevelComment.author: Robert Foster
topLevelComment.text:
Does this video also count for ES6 new technology. Because she is using var instead of let.
and since javascript currently as of June 2018 says that var is no longer used and is replaced by let - The question is are there many other things that are changed to the point that will make this video null and void ?
Which means (freeCodeCamp) will need to upload new video of this exact topic that covers the new updated javascript ES6 and such....
Thats my concern about these videos that I have old code methods as of the current date of June 2018

replies.author: Paul M Edwards
replies.text: var can still be used, but let is preferred. There are articles online explaining why.

topLevelComment.author: Brian Regalado
topLevelComment.text: Can someone explain to me what she is looking for in the first 10 minutes? Is she to check if the string is within the object and what does the addition of one mean.

replies.author: Jennifer Bland
replies.text: You are welcome. Good luck on your journey to learn coding.

replies.author: Brian Regalado
replies.text: Thank you very much, I quite new to coding so that means a lot that you are willing to communicate with me.

replies.author: Jennifer Bland
replies.text: Great question. I am using an object which is made up of key-value pairs. Each key has to be unique so I am using that to count the occurrence of each letter by letting the letter be the key and the value being the total count of occurances. The first time I come across a letter, I put it in the object with the letter as the key and the value of 1. If I find that letter again, they key will exist in the object so I just increment the value by one. By the end I have each letter and the total number of occurrences.

replies.author: Zak Jacobson
replies.text: B R - she's counting the occurences of each letter in a string. For example, if the string (str) was "Hello" the result would be {h=1, e=1, l=2, o=1}

topLevelComment.author: Selestine Mtei
topLevelComment.text: Nice tutorial and insights Jennifer. But I think at minute 34:55, you said we should use join() but you used split() which won't work since Array doesn't have a split method.

replies.author: Gray Smith
replies.text: i was thinking this as well, thanks for mentioning it.

replies.author: Jennifer Bland
replies.text: good catch. Yes it should be join()

replies.author: Sai Krishna
replies.text: she's chaining the methods right? So, .split(), is on the string which is a String method (returns an Array object, I think) and then she proceeds to .reverse(), which is an Array method and then .join()! You are right, Array object doesn't have split() method but String object does that returns an Array Object!

replies.author: kick buttowski
replies.text: I agree

topLevelComment.author: Murray Rothbard
topLevelComment.text:
Good one.
I would add the following:

- Could use some more modern JS here. forEach, e.g.

- One could use the idea behind counting sorting, without the ordering step. It's linear and with not need for mutation.

replies.author: Breakpoint
replies.text: you can't break from a forEach which might make it a bad use case sometimes for certain algorithms
